frameDefinitions: The words in this frame describe acts (or situations characterized by acts) that cause injury or harm.
An Agent causes a Useful_location to become accessible (or non-accessible) to a Theme to a certain Degree.
This frame concerns the infliction of punishment in return for a wrong suffered.

An Assailant, a group of armed forces, surrounds the Victim, a military location and the people within it, in an attempt to cut the Victim off from the outside, with the goal of either forcing their surrender or weakening them so that an invasion would be successful.
An individual or group, the Rebel, rejects the authority of the Current_leadership, and attempts to bring them out of power.
A Combatant is declared or loyal to a Side in a military Conflict.
frameExamples: Research on whether concealed carry laws increase gun <t>violence</t> among gang members has been inconclusive.
They've <t>blockaded</t> the entrance -- no one can get in or out.
(1) They took <t>revenge</t> for the deaths of two loyalist prisoners.
Towards the end of the summer, a great English host <t>besieged</t> the Danish fort of Tempsford and took it, killing the last Danish king of East Anglia.
In 1641 there was a Catholic <t>rebellion</t> against the Protestants of Ulster, and English authority over the island was shaken.
A 20-year=old Argentinian <t>guerilla</t> was firing at our squad.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Aggressor</fen> is the person causing the <fen>Victim</fen>'s injury.
The <fen>Victim</fen> is the being or entity that is injured.
The <fen>Cause</fen> marks expressions that indicate some non-intentional, typically non-human, force that inflicts harm on the <fen>Victim</fen>
The <fen>Aggressors</fen> commit acts of violence upon each other.
<fen>Time</fen> identifies the time when the harm-causing event occurs.
<fen>Place</fen> identifies the place where the violence occurs.
The <fen>Agent</fen> blocks access to the <fen>Useful_location</fen>.
The <fen>Useful_location</fen> is the place the <fen>Theme</fen> is headed towards and the <fen>Agent</fen> has changed the accessibility of.

The <fen>Agent</fen> may regulate access to the <fen>Useful_location</fen> by regulating access to a <fen>Portal</fen>, including a part of the portal that could block potential <fen>Theme</fen>s, such as doors or gates.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> changes the accessibility of the <fen>Useful_location</fen>.
The general <fen>Place</fen> where the blocking or allowing of access occurs.
The <fen>Avenger</fen> exacts revenge from the <fen>Offender</fen> for the <fen>Injury</fen>.
The <fen>Offender</fen> has committed the earlier <fen>Injury</fen> for which the <fen>Avenger</fen> seeks revenge.
The <fen>Avenger</fen> carries out a <fen>Punishment</fen> in order to exact revenge on the <fen>Offender</fen>.

The <fen>Injury</fen> is the injurious action committed by the <fen>Offender</fen> against the <fen>Injured_Party</fen>. This Frame Element need not always be realized, although it is conceptually necessary.

This frame element identifies the constituent that encodes who or what suffered the <fen>Injury</fen> at the hands of the <fen>Offender</fen>. Sometimes, an abstract concept such a person's honour or their blood is presented as the element that has suffered the <fen>Injury</fen>. These also constitute instances of  <fen>Injured_party</fen>
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the revenge occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the revenge occurs.

The <fen>Assailant</fen> is a group of armed forces (or, metonymically, their commander or the organization they represent) that encircles, surrounds, or otherwise cuts off the Beseiged in an attempt to force surrender.
The <fen>Victim</fen> is the fortification or geopolitical entity that is being attacked.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Assailant</fen> attacks the <fen>Victim</fen>.
This role identifies the place where the <fen>Assailant</fen> makes an assault on the <fen>Victim</fen>.
The individual or group within a society that attempts to overturn the <fen>Current_leadership</fen>, and possibly also the <fen>Current_order</fen> of governance.
The people currently in power, whom the <fen>Rebel</fen>s attempt to overthrow.
The currently-existing system of authority or government.
The time when the rebellion takes place.
The location of the rebellion.
The <fen>Combatant</fen> is the human being involved in combat.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Your</fex> brutality on your enemies seems to know no boundaries.
Increasing violence against supporters of government reform have attracted international attention.
<fex>The storm's</fex> violence left many lives in shambles.
Hope for a peaceful resoliton is gone as violence <fex>between the two sides</fex> reignites.
<fex>Last week's</fex> violence resulted in over three hundred injuries.
City leaders are troubled by recent surges in <fex>local</fex> violence
<fex>Police</fex> have cordoned off the area where the crime took place.
Protestors barricaded <fex>a highway that connects the industrial sectors to the ports</fex>.
They've blockaded <fex>the entrance</fex> -- no one can get in or out.
A rebel group blockaded the roadways <fex>late last night</fex>.
Many roads were cordorned off <fex>in the central district</fex> right after the incident.
<fex>We</fex> want to avenge her.
Jo had the affair as a kind of revenge <fex>against Pat</fex>.
The team took revenge <fex>with a resounding victory</fex>.
The team sought revenge <fex>for their 4-1 defeat last month</fex>.
Sam's brothers avenged <fex>him</fex>.
In 1641 there was a <fex>Catholic</fex> rebellion against the Protestants of Ulster, and English authority over the island was shaken.
It was the first time that a man of such high rank had been put to death for rebellion <fex>against the king</fex>.
At the time they were in rebellion <fex>against the Catholic government</fex>.
Did you support the insurrection <fex>of 1854</fex>?
It seems probably that rebellion <fex>in East Anglia</fex> was as rigorously suppressed as in Kent.
